SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: LENAMAY PURDY
Present Address: BALCARRES, SASK.
Pioneer Address: REGINA, PENSE, WASCANA, living in same place since moved.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1883

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Visits were not frequent, but we went some distance and several families came in P.E.I. In the P.E.I., we visited occasionally about 1892-1893. How many of these were bachelor's homes? My father visited several bachelor's homes with his children where there were ladies.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Regularly.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sundays we sometimes had church services at home, those from a distance were invited to dinner, helped with chores, etc.

4. Was it often difficult to get to the house, or was visiting done without an invitation? Few invitations, but always very welcoming, especially sometimes they would help neighbors with building something, etc., and the women would be so homely the time of day.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? 

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Among our neighbors, we often used the phrase "potluck," which meant a casual gathering with no set rules. We were all glad to have visitors, especially women, though I have felt myself go out afterwards when I knew someone coming.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? A few would offer a cup of tea, but with coffee extended our welcome.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Then things got going better by the last spring, and we had a lot of work done in 1897. Bees were arranged for the building of large barns. Bees were arranged for the raising of sheep, and the ladies provided refreshments. After raising, we settled on little plots in the yard. This was in 1899.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were a good many dances in the P.E.I. station, but they were larger than in our house. Bachelor boys together, no ladies, cards, etc. Sometimes we had dancing parties, but we never had music. Sometimes we had refreshments and games, and sometimes we had music provided by each other. The homes were very simple, for living and simple.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates, if possible, when played.

In the '90s there were more families and we went quite a long way to get together two or three times a month to play games. Some evenings included music, but we didn't have any school. Would you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No, in the Cottonwood district.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, FAMILIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many houses were there in your neighborhood? How many of them were inhabited by families? How many by single people?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Regularly?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days? During what part of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? You often through.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take pity" used, or was some other expression?)

4. How often did you attend parties? Regularly?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have these when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activities?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in town? Describe.

There were parties and dances in town.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Visits were not frequent, but we went some distance and several families came in. In the fall, we visited occasionally.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? My father visited several bachelor's homes.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Irregularly.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sundays, we sometimes had church services in homes that were visited during the week.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Few invitations, but bachelors were always ready to help each other.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Yes, often thereafter.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, often thereafter.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Among our neighbors, especially in the early days, there was a casual attitude toward such things.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? A cup of tea, but visits were extended over small talk.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? The first gathering was held in 1897.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

After I was married in 1897, a good many farmers were able to build large barns. Bees were arranged for the raising, and the ladies provided refreshments. After raising, we stables on the farm.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were a good many dances in the R.R. Station, as well as at the homes where larger than average houses were built. Bachelor's got together to have dancing parties. Sometimes, there were attempts to have skating parties. These were followed by refreshments and games. The women would make refreshments, and the men would play games.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

In the '90s there were more families and the winter was quite a long time, so there were more parties held in the homes.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No, in the Cottonwood district.
SASKATOON ARMIES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were there in your neighborhood? How many of these were bachelor's homes? How many were married couples' homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? During what time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days during the week? What was your usual purpose for visiting?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or did most visiting done without an invitation? If so, what was the purpose of visiting?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? How often thereafter?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "to make excuse" used, or was some other expression common?)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such projects? Tell what you remember about such gatherings; giving dates if possible; telling what the "bees" were for, and how they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe them.

Tell what you remember about any kind of informal social gatherings, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times; every two weeks once a week, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? At Cordova Boggy Creek hall was built in the church hall about 1922.

What material was it made of? Timber

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The Anglican Church helped.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)

This hall was used for church services, school meetings, and other gatherings. It was used for parties, dances, and other events.

When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

The hall at Cordova was very large and well arranged.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

There were a good many Methodists and among these people there was no card playing. There were families and groups who played cards for fun, and there were others who mostly bachelors who played for stakes, sometimes rather high; there were also quarts among them.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, book donations, and other activities (Include also the school Christmas tree, plants, etc.). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? How was it built?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) The local school house was used for various purposes such as:

- Religious services
- Community meetings
- School events

When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9), and 10) did the entire family attend?

You were brides and small children provided free.

As the demand for larger and more elaborate facilities increased, the hall was expanded to meet these needs.

What other games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

There were also parties and social gatherings held at the schoolhouse. These parties included birthday parties, anniversary parties, and community gatherings.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?
Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Near the Redfield Valley north of the Cottonwood neighborhood, a ring to boggy creek was made, and young folks went there often to play. Mrs. Belfour, a lady who homesteaded with her family, house and dugout near the valley, made us all welcome for a picnic. We picnicked into their stable. They were not richly, but we enjoyed it.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?
When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

14. Describe any other details of chivalry, parties, etc., that you remember, telling if you know approximate dates or not, and how popular it was in your town or community.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers Local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

I think in Regina from 1910 to 1925 and subscribed to Country drugs. In Regina I belonged to the Red St. Ladies Aid, to the W.C.T.U., to the Wagner Liberal Women's Club, and to the Regina Horticultural Society. I taught in the S.S. for several winters and a group of the loyal temperance league met once a week. We would go to the schools and help sometimes with the field work. The C.W.C.A., where my boys were members.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, describe some of these activities. Give dates if possible.

Speakers at our horticultural meetings include Mrs. A. P. E., Carwell, etc., John Walter and others from Indiana. Talks on Forestry Farm.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Run the farm, prisoners play baseball, etc.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Girls played with the boys. Sometimes both played house.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, what were the subjects? Who gave them? (Local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.)? Where were they held? How well attended were they? Any other details you remember about them?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (sandlot-type ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? What games did girls play in summer (slingshot rope, play house, etc.)?

That games did children play during the day? That games did children play at night?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others; checkers or other games? In my childhood home we played Authors, table games, Scrabble, etc. Sometimes we played Monopoly (this was good for me as I played mostly with my parents). We also played spelling bee, word games, etc.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

All of us, and any victory present.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

In winter we seemed to have a good deal of time in the evenings. Sometimes Mother and the girls went outside playing the question and answer game.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

We dug caves in big snow drifts, made model homesteads in the snow, etc.

PROMS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

May 24th, 1884 at the Old Crossing on Wasana Creek.

26. Who organized it?

The first settlers who had arrived there in May 24th, 1882, Martin, Henderson, Callender, Cochrane, etc.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? For everybody. It became an annual event continued for many years.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? 1883.

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

I think that picnic in '84 was mainly all visiting and getting acquainted. Later there was usually some picked out by someone. Now the first consideration was to produce a large flat table-like top with enough room to hold a large amount of food.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? A committee provided hot water, groups cooked to gather around clothes on the grass, making their own tents. After tables were built with seats and umbrellas, picnickers combined their supplies.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Sandwiches, pickles, cakes and cookies, salads - the 24th was too early for our gardens.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

So we could have our dinner if the weather was fine we stayed late for supper.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - curling games such as "Happy Family," "Hunters," "Happy Family," "Children's Games," etc.? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? 

Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? 

Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, spoons, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? 

Describe.

25. What was the date of the first pionto that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give the month if possible.

26. The annual meeting was held at what place? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

Describe an annual event continued for many years.

28. Was it the first pionto held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the arrangements at the pionto you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

Describe.

30. What arrangements were made for eating? 

Families and friends from small groups came together to have a meal. 

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

Describe.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

Describe.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

I remember a heart-piercing sound when sudden storms swept over the picnic, causing a small tent to fly higgledy-piggledy, and everyone was confused. Some ladies lost their bonnets, while others shrieked, but no one hurt. That was in 1928, I remember correctly.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

There was an annual picnic at Carnevala in the Apple Valley each year. It was always on July 3rd and was not a large picnic. There were long tables with benches, a place to wash dishes, other good arrangements. Anybody came who could come from long distances, who you could find. Horses were the only transportation power. There were usually guest speakers, N.F. Davis, Webster, and many others during the year.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

I am living now near Valcartier. The usual picnics in this district seem to be the Sunday school picnics and little family picnics. There have been a few big political picnics, such as the gathering when Mr. St. Laurent came to Apple Valley.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

The sports of yesteryear were strictly amateur. There was baseball, softball, soccer, attempts by many Englishmen at cricket, a few games of handball, tennis, bowling, and some shooting sports. Most of these were enjoyed and had traditions.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the annual picnic of the school, church, or Sunday School, family picnics, etc., and tell what differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, were held, if so.

35. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). How did it come about?

36. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving dates of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local opera days, entered in competition in larger contests, etc.

37. For what team was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

That year?

How long did it continue?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

My mother brought quite a large library consisting of a good selection of works of poetry, much of Scott novels, historical works, such books as travel stories, travels, tales by Dickens, around the Dark Continent, two large volumes containing races of the world, Robinson Crusoe, Arabian Nights, Gulliver's Travels, many more, including books she and my mother had read and enjoyed. When we had a little money to spare we added to these.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Two or three.
   What kind of books and how many? Those we knew had real literature.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? We exchanged a few.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. We bought missionary school books, as we children studied at home, we constantly added to our library, friends in Ontario gave us books.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? I can only mention a few, a physiology from Ontario school, King's Life Illustrated, a little Bible, a copy of Dickens Works, a year's numbers of Ladies' Home Journal, and many more.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

Now of course books can be had from Regina, from the Wheat Pool Library etc.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   We took the Regina Leader when Mr. Davis was editor and publisher. Later generally had the Weekly Globe from Toronto. Friends sent us bundles of S.S. papers from Ontario. For awhile we took a little magazine called "Truth." And we had the Christian Guardian and the Northern Messenger.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
   When I started to teach school I wanted a paper. The people where I boarded looked for a little local paper. Then a small town in Butte, Montana, subscribed for the Montana Weekly Tribune. Later on we took the North West Farmer, the Winnipeg Tribune, the Winnipeg Tribune, the Grain Growers Guide, etc.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No.

   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   Mother's library was divided among the family. Some books given to local public library. I have a good many of her books and many added to my collection since.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. During the 1885 rebellion we often wished for quicker news. A postmaster friend, Mr. Johnson, would bring newspapers from England and Canada and read them aloud. We learned patience and our bookcases as well used at times allowed.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   Who was it started by?
   In what year did it exist?
   If not, when was it discarded, and why?

Give any other details which you can about this library - how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to this town?

52. Describe later changes in your subscription and what they included.

53. Did you ever attend the free monthly lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? How often?

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
Mother brought a good piano organ.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
One man played a violin, another a little farther away played a piccolo.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
About 1933 bought a viola through a mail order company for $25.00. In 1943 bought a piano through a mail order company for $150.00.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
A great deal. Mother sang at her times during the day, and Father sang at his times during the evening. We had a good and large collection of hymns, we always sang, and attended church services regularly.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Name some old songs.
There were many old songs, such as "Home Sweet Home," "The Old Folks at Home," etc.

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
No, but the teacher at Boggy Creek School who was so musical, Mr. Ward, made up words for several songs my children learned.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Here at Balcarres many children take music lessons. We have a more or less musical singing-song at public affairs. We have a fairly good church choir and a promising junior choir which is doing well in the Music Festival.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

I have kept a diary making a few notes on weather as well as farm and house activities but nothing very consistent. I keep track of time different varieties planted in garden and kind of gardening etc.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I take an interest in our horticultural society; one daughter and I work together in our garden and for our hay exhibit. I make braided and hooked rugs and pictures.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

We had a handicraft club and a good many in this Balcarres community have done lovely leatherwork shell work, petit-point, oil pictures and one lady, Mrs. Mel Wilson does creditable oil painting. She enters us to show does very fine GENERAL oil paintings, and our W.A. sponsored a large exhibit of his paintings.
